title: Materials with market value: Global ceramic and glass industry poised to reach $1 trillioin
Analysis of regenerator energy performance with the HEAT BALANCE computer model
abstract: The HEAT BALANCE computer model performs analytical energy balances for conventional fuel-fired glass furnaces. The model was used repeatedly to analyze various regenerator configurations. Some of the energy-related trends which occur relative to regenerator design alternatives are summarized.

title: Integrated type amorphous silicon solar cell
abstract: Two main technologies for low cost solar cells using amorphous silicon (a-Si) film have been developed. A new PCVD (Plasma Chemical Vapor Deposition) fabrication process in which p,i, and n layers of a-Si are deposited in consecutive, separated reaction chambers, has been developed. In this process, high quality a-Si films are produced, because the undesirable mixing of dopants is prevented. And a new type of solar cell, an integrated type a-Si solar cell module in which several a-Si solar cells are connected in series, and which can generate high voltage from a single substrate, has also been developed. The optimum design theory for this new type of solar cell module is discussed here. The mass production of this type cell module has already begun for use in consumer applications. A 2kW class demonstration plant consisting of a-Si solar cell panels was constructed for the development of a power generating system.

title: Improving firing consistency
abstract: In these times of uncertain economy and with cost reduction programs directed toward achieving higher profitability, it often becomes necessary to operate existing equipment to its limit and sometimes beyond. This is especially true for kilns used in the ceramic industry, where it has become the norm to expect to achieve higher production figures than those for which the kiln was originally designed. What are some of the factors that prevent the operating of these kilns to even higher production levels without sacrificing ware quality? Although this discussion focuses primarily on direct-fired tunnel kilns--which are typically divided in offtake/preheat zone, furnace zone, rapid cooling zone, and regular cooling zone--the subject matter addressed can be applied to periodic kilns as well.

title: Acoustic microscopy of silicon carbide materials
authors: P. Khandelwal; P. W. Heitman; D. Yuhas; Carol Vorres
abstract: It is shown that scanning laser acoustic microscopy (SLAM) is able to detect such fracture-controlling flaws in dense silicon carbide materials as surface voids, whose diameter-by-depth size is a minimum of 75 by 17 microns in reaction-bonded SiC and 68 by 25 microns in alpha-SiC. Surface conditions such as pitting, which have been found to limit the discernibility of drilled holes, become important when pit and drilled hole sizes become comparable.

title: Properties of mortars containing fine-ground cements
authors: F. F. Lange; H. Moertel; V. Rudert
abstract: Fine-ground cements, such as Mikrodur{reg_sign} have wider particle size distributions than ordinary cements. The wider distribution has a significant influence on the properties of resulting mortars. This phenomenon is commonly known as the filler effect. Silica-fume and fly ash usually are used as additives to the cement. They enhance mortar strength--by affecting microstructure--and durability. The present work demonstrates that it is possible to enhance mortar properties by blending them with Mikrodur, a fine blast-furnace-slag-based cement, which is characterized by its maximum particle size. Maximum particle size is the basis for the different available grades of Mikrodur. Each grade has a similar influence on mortar properties. Overall mortar properties are influenced by the grade and mass percentage of fine-ground cement used.

title: Cyclic fatigue life of SiAlON at room temperature
authors: Thomas J. Whalen; J. R. Baer; W. J. Trela; R. K. Govila
abstract: The fatigue life of a SiAlON material was evaluated at room temperature in a rotating beam tester. No significant effect of stress level was determined. Failure origins were associated with processing and powder impurities, and consisted primarily of porosity and inclusions in the bulk material. The experimental design was such that a sufficient number of failures at each stress level would produce a good estimate of the distribution, and a test of the influence of a high stress level on fatigue life could be achieved.

title: IRRADIATION-INDUCED PHASE CHANGES IN ZrO$sub 2$-UO$sub 2$ FUELS
abstract: After comparatively small amounts of neutron irradiation, multiphase mixtures in the ZrO/sub 2/--UO/sub 2/ binary system combine into a single phase. Above 8 x 10/sup 20/ fissions/cc, this single phase is cubic. This cubic phase is apparently continuous from UO/sub 2/ to ZrO/sub 2/. The cell edge varies linearly with molar composition, but not significantly with radiation exposure. It is postulated that there exists a hightemperature cubic phase which cannot be quenched using ordinary furnace techniques at compositions with less than 70 wt% UO/sub 2/. (auth)

title: Effect of Heat Treatment on the Strength of Glass Cylinders as Determined by a Diametral Loading Techniaue
authors: P. D. Ownby; Delbert E. Day; Robert E. Moore

title: Trends in powder processing equipment
abstract: Spray drying is the most widely used process for producing particles. It is used in industries other than ceramics including food, chemicals, and pharmaceutical. The process involves the atomization of a liquid feed stock into a spray of droplets and contacting the droplets with hot air in a drying chamber. The sprays are produced by either rotary or nozzle atomizers. Evaporation of moisture from the droplets and formation of dry particles proceed under controlled temperature and airflow conditions. Powder is then discharged continuously from the drying chamber. Spray drying equipment is being improved to handle an ever-increasing number of applications. Several developments in particle-size reduction equipment are also described.

title: Hot extrusion of high-temperature superconducting oxides
authors: U. Balachandran; R.B. Poeppel; James G. Hunt
abstract: This paper reports tht since the discovery of high-critical temperature (high-T{sub c}) superconductors, many applications have been envisioned, ranging from small-scale items such as electronic components to large-scale devices for generating, storing, and distributing energy. Superconducting components for small-scale applications can be fabricated by thin-film techniques, which have produced the best superconductor performance to date. Large-scale applications of high-temperature superconductors require long, continuous lengths of conductor. It may be possible to fabricate such lengths by room-temperature plastic extrusion or fiber spinning, a powder-in-tube technique, or a high-temperature hot-extrusion process. Because each method involves directional processing, development of favorable grain alignment is possible. The relationship of grain alignment to transport critical current density in high-T{sub c} materials has been reviewed by Kroeger.

title: Influence of surfactants on contact angles of ceramic brick-aqueous solution-air and sand lime brick-aqueous solution-air
abstract: Surfactants influence the contact angles of cerarnic brick-aqueous solution-air to a larger extent than contact angles of sand lirne brick-aqueous solution-air. This ap­ plies especial1y to re ceding contact angles. Surfactants are rernoved frorn the solution by sand lirne brick to a larger extent than by ceramic brick. T he increasing use of surfactants as air entrainers or super­ plasticizers in cementitious systems leads to the question: Do these additives influence the capillary suction exerted by bric1es on the water phase in mortars? This suction is determined by the average pore si ze in the brick and by the contact angles at the three phase boundaries of brick-aqueous solution-air. Both factors may differ for ceramic brick versus sand lime brick.  The present investigation aims to elucidate whether surfac­ ta'nts influence the contact angles on those materiais. Two pure compounds and two commercial substances were used as sur­ factants.

title: Combustion gas corrosion resistance of heat-exchange materials and refractories for glass furnaces at high temperatures; Part II: Oxides and composites
authors: Wen‐Yi Lin; J. T. Hsu; Y. Berta; Robert F. Speyer
abstract: This article continues the description of the stability of glass furnace refractories and heat exchange materials in combustion environments. Part one of this study was presented last month. The results of testing of composites and oxides are presented here. In this study, Al[sub 2]TiO[sub 5]-Al[sub 6]Si[sub 2]O[sub 13] composites were selected as a candidate material based on its thermal shock resistance. Chromic oxide was also selected because of its high corrosion resistance.

title: Implications of Computer-Based Simulation Models, Expert Systems, Databases, and Networks for Advancing Cement Research
Dry scrubbing controls kiln emissions
abstract: The Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 require that industrial emissions be significantly reduced by 2000, and some states require reductions with earlier deadlines. This is a critical time for US ceramic industries. There are only a few ways to conform to the upcoming regulations, singularly or in combination: change the composition of raw materials, change the way kilns are operated and/or install air pollution control equipment.

title: Ceramic EMI Filters - A Review
abstract: Ceramic EMI filters provide a superior solution to the problem of controlling EMI in advanced, high-reliability, high-performance electronic systems. The manufacturing technology for multilayer chip capacitors, which has evolved over the past 25 years, has been applied to the manufacture of discoidal multilayer ceramic capacitors. These unique capacitors provide the filter manufacturer with a spectrum of design capabilities and the ruggedness necessary to perform in a variety of hostile environments.

title: RECLAIM : California's guarantee for cleaner air
abstract: California's south coast air basin--the Los Angeles area--suffers the worst air pollution in the US, even after a history of extraordinary actions taken to reduce pollution. Existing regulations are tough and demanding, but must be changed to achieve federal clean air health standards by 2010. The Southern California business community and public are aggressively pursuing use of market incentives to lower the cost of achieving cleaner air. The South Coast Air Quality Management District (SCAQMD) is developing an alternative market-based regulatory approach called the Regional Clean Air Incentives Market (RECLAIM) program. RECLAIM has the potential to clean up air more effectively than traditional regulations by harnessing the power of the marketplace. Compared to the existing Air Quality Management Plan (AQMP), RECLAIM is designed to ensure that the program achieves equivalent emission reductions, an equal or greater level of enforcement, lower implementation costs, fewer job impacts and no adverse public health impacts.

title: Simulated nuclear waste glass leaching: Alteration layer artifacts produced by reprecipitation of solutes during cooling
abstract: Most nuclear waste glass leaching/corrosion experiments are conducted under hydrothermal conditions with continuous contact between the glass sample and leachate. During the cooling phase at the conclusion of the experiment, material removed to solution may reprecipitate onto the glass sample, giving rise to alteration layer morphologies and compositions not representative of those existing at high temperatures. The reprecipitation effect is shown to be significant in 28-day experiments conducted at 190/sup 0/C.

title: Computer-aided imaging in ceramics
authors: JJ Friel; Victor A. Greenhut; Javier Oliver
abstract: Quantitative microscopy has been used on materials for many years for establishing and meeting material specifications or relating process to properties. However, quantitative image analysis is used less extensively for ceramography than for metallography. Perhaps this is due to lack of suitable etchants for ceramic phases, lack of contrast mechanisms for either light optical or electron microscope, or lack of clear microstructural specification in ceramics. When computerized image analyzers became widely available over 10 years ago, materials scientists immediately put them to use for metals, but less so for ceramics. Now computer power and software are routinely and inexpensively available not only for rapid image analysis of thousands of particles or grains but also for the difficult image processing that is sometimes necessary to prepare images of ceramics for analysis. The tool has advanced to the point where it can be an important aid in quality control, production, R and D, and product specification. This paper provides examples of applications of computer-aided imaging to ceramics.

title: Continuous particulate monitoring for emission control
abstract: An optical continuous particle monitoring system has been developed to overcome common problems associated with emissions monitoring equipment. Opacity monitors generally use a single- or double-pass system to analyze the presence of dust particles in the flue gas stream. The particles scatter and absorb light as it passes through the stack. As the particle content in the gas stream increases due to bag failure or some other problem, the amount of light that is blocked also increases. The opacity monitor compares the amount of lost light energy to the total energy of the light available and translates the signal to percentage of opacity. Opacity monitors are typically installed to meet the requirements set forth by pollution control agencies. Most opacity monitors are designed to meet all of the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) 40 CFR, Part 60, Appendix B, Performance Specification. The new continuous particle monitor (CPM) increases the accuracy of emission monitoring and overcomes typical problems found in conventional emission monitoring devices. The CPM is an optically based, calibratible, continuous dust monitor that uses a microprocessor, transmitter head, and receiver head. When calibrated with an isokinetic sample, a continuous readout of particulate concentration (in mg/m[sup 3]) inmore » the exhaust gas is provided. The system can be used as a filter bag failure system or a long-term emission trend analyzer. Formal testing was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of the optically based CPM. The monitor was calibrated using particles of a range of compositions, size distributions, and concentrations. The feasibility of using the instrument to measure particle concentration as low as 10 mg/m[sup 3] was examined.« less

title: Improved insulation for an induction-heated ZrO/sub 2/ furnace
authors: Sun Keguang; Richard Pike; A.T. Chapman
abstract: The induction-heated ZrO/sub 2/ muffle furnace is extensively used for the production of silica fibers used as optical waveguides in the communications industry. The furnace typically operates in air between 2200/sup 0/ and 2300/sup 0/C. Improved materials and design that will increase the life, the operating temperature, as well as the physical size and particulate cleanliness of the furnace atmosphere, are continually being sought. This note describes the general makeup and operating characteristics of the furnace and the improved performance achieved by using skull-melted ZrO/sub 2/ grain (grog) as the insulating material surrounding and supporting the ZrO/sub 2/ heater (muffle). Noteworthy milestones in the development of oxides as a direct heating element have been made.

BEHAVIOR OF ILLITE ON HEATING
authors: G. C. Phillips; Wayne Ernest Brownell
abstract: A study was made on purified Fithian illite in the temperature range from 100 to 1000 deg C. Dehydration behavior was investigated by relating weight-loss determinations and differential thermal analysis. Structural changes were studied by X-ray diffraction analysis, surface area determination, and electron microscopy. Illite loses its lattice water without any apparent change in crystallinity. The dehydrated structure structure consolidates prior to the lattice breakdown and crystallization. Initial phases crystallize from the the octahedral layer of the illite structure. /Author/

SCREEN PRINTED CAPACITOR DIELECTRICS
abstract: Abstract Dielectrics yielding K′s of 400–800 and dissipation factors of less than 2 per cent are available as screen printing pastes. The dielectrics fit alumina substrates, are compatible with presently popular electrode compositions like Du Pont 7553 platinum-gold and may be fired in the range of 750–1050°C by the same time schedules presently used for thick-film conductor-resistor networks. Data on capacitance vs. voltage, temperature and frequency are presented as well as hysteresis loop and X-ray diffraction properties.

FOAMED CLAY-WATER SYSTEMS FOR LEIGHTWEIGHT AGGREGATE PRODUCTION
authors: M F Modde; W. G. Lawrence
abstract: A METHOD OF PRODUCING A LIGHTWEIGHT AGGREGATE BY THE FOAMING OF A CLAY SLIP AND STABILIZING IT IN THE FORM OF PELLETS IS DESCRIBED. THE CLAY-WATER SLIP WAS PREPARED USING A VARIABLE SPEED MIXER. SMALL ADDITIONS OF BALL CLAY WERE DESIRABLE TO IMPROVE THE DRY STRENGTH OF THE PELLETS PRODUCED. THE PELLETS WERE DRIED OVERNIGHT IN A CIRCULATING AIR DRIVER. THE FIRED PELLETS HAVE BULK DENSITIES OF 35-47 LB/FT. SATISFACTORY LIGHTWEIGHT AGGREGATE WAS OBTAINED FROM NONBLOATING MATERIALS BY THE FOAMED SLURRY PROCESS. THE ELIMINATION OF ADDITIVES, PRIOR PARTICLE SIZING, SPECIAL KILN EQUIPMENT WITH CAREFULLY CONTROLLED TEMPERATURE ZONES AS WELL AS KILN ATMOSPHERE CONTROL MAY BE POSSIBLE ADVANTAGES. THE METHOD OFFERS A MEANS OF PRODUCING LIGHTWEIGHT AGGREGATE FROM CLAYS, SHALES OR OTHER OXIDES WHICH ARE NOT NATURAL BLOATING MATERIALS.

STRENGTH OF DRIED CLAY - A REVIEW
abstract: A COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW OF THE LITERATURE ON FRACTURE MECHANISMS AND STRENGTH CHARACTERISTICS OF DRY OR NEARDRY CLAYS IS PRESENTED. FRACTURE INVOLVES THE BREAKING OF BONDS BETWEEN CRYSTALS OR CRYSTALLINE AGGREGATES, RATHER THAN WITHIN THE CRYSTALS THEMSELVES. HYDRATED OR DEHYDRATED IONS, CRYSTALLIZED SALTS, CEMENTITIOUS IMPURITIES INCLUDING GEL- FORMERS, AND THE SURFACE TENSION AND VISCOSITY OF THE INTERSTITIAL LIQUID, CAN BE INVOLVED IN BONDING. VAN DER WAALS FORCES MAY BE LESS SIGNIFICANT. A STRONG BOND CAN RESULT IN AN OPENTEXTURED WEAK TEST PIECE. ISOTROPIC AND ANISOTROPIC STRENGTH IS RELATED TO FLAWS IN THE MICROSTRUC- TURE. CERTAIN FLAWS RESULT FROM OSBORNE REYNOLDS DILATANCY OR ARISE IN SLIP BANDS WHICH DEVELOP DURING PLASTICE DEFORMATION. NONPLASTICS IN LIMITED ANOUNTS MAY INCREASE STRENGTH BY BLOCKING CRACK-PROPAGATION ALONG SLIP BANDS. STRENGTH CAN BE TREATED THERMODYNAMICALLY WITHOUT DIRECT REFERENCE TO BONDING MECHANISMS OR MICROSTRUCTURES. /ACSB/

title: A COAXIAL CYLINDER RHEOMETER FOR GEL STRUCTURE CHARACTERIZATION
authors: J C Sikra; Harold T. Smyth; G W Phelps
abstract: A SENSITIVE COAXIAL CYLINDER RHEOMETER WAS BUILT AND CALIBRATED WITH A NEWTONIAN FLUID. THE RHEOMETER IS OF THE COAXIAL CYLINDER TYPE IN WHICH A BOB ROTATES IN A STATIONARY CUP. THE AMOUNT AND/OR RATE OF ROTATION OF THE BOB IS MEASURED OVER A LIMITED RANGE BY THE MOTION OF A REFLECTED LIGHT BEAM. OPERATING CHARACTERISTICS OF THE INSTRUMENT WERE FURTHER INVESTIGATED USING A CERAMIC SLIP. IT WAS SHOWN THAT THE INSTRUMENT IS CAPABLE OF APPLYING SHEARING STRESSES LESS THAN THOSE REQUIRED TO CAUSE A GELLED SLIP TO FLOW. RESPONSE OF A GELLED SLIP TO THESE LOW STRESSES RESEMBLED VISCOELASTIC BEHAVIOR. /AUTHOR/

abstract: The investigation and characterization of tobermorites and the synthetic hydrates C-S-H(I) and C-S-H gel are reviewed, with particular attention to the application of X-ray diffractometry, ir spectrophotometry, electron microscopy, and differential thermal analysis. /Author/

title: Powder Standard Reference Materials | NIST
GRINDING STONE AND CONCRETE WITH COATED ABRASIVES
authors: R.C. Lokken; William J. McDonald; E. J. Duwell
abstract: Silicon carbide coated abrasives grind stone or concrete most efficiently when run dry and at high speeds. This high energy process appears to heat the surface layer of the workpiece to temperatures which make chip formation easy. However, neither the ground surface of the workpiece nor the coated abrasive is thermally damaged to any significant degree. Dry dust collection may be an attractive alternative to the removal of wet debris in water lubricated operations. Brick for construction or for refractory applications could possibly be ground by this method. Prefabricated terrazzo made with either polymeric or inorganic grouts are also candidates for dimensioning and finishing by this process. A great many other applications may exist which could be carried out with suitably designed equipment. These include the large scale grinding of roads, bridge abutments, airport runways and concrete walls, the texturing of road surfaces for skid resistance, and the removal of traffic marking paints.

title: STATISTICS IN SAMPLING OF BULK MATERIAL
authors: W C Hackler; T E Caltfelter; J M Farley; C L Hackler; E W Rilee
abstract: Estimates of the variability at four sampling stages are determined to evaluate the quality of outgoing shipments of kyanite. Several sampling plans are presented along with the associated variance of average kyanite content for each plan. The minimum sample size required to detect a specified shift in the process average is computed. The results of taking a composite sample from a day's production are evaluated along with the variance for the composite. The following conclusions are reached: (1) Evidence indicates good engineering practices in the mining and beneficiation of the kyanite; (2) More precise estimates of the actual quality of the outgoing material will result from improvements in the analytical laboratory; (3) Sampling plans are designed which will determine the minimum number of analyses or which will detect a specified shift in the process average; and (4) Care must be exercised in the use of composite samples.

title: CUT FUEL COSTS IN THE LIGHTWEIGHT AGGREGATE INDUSTRY
abstract: This article shows how the use of proper equipment in the lightweight aggregate industry decreases fuel consumption. The heat consumption of a typical 1000 ton-day lightweight aggregate kiln is estimated to be 4,004,215 Btu/ton of product. When operating at reduced capacity, the heat consumption is increased to approximately 4,180,918 Btu/ton. The same kiln with the addition of a grate cooler at full capacity shows a heat consumption of approximately 2,716,356 Btu/ton. In addition to this fuel saving, the grate cooler permits the material to be conveyed directly to storage on rubber belts, thereby eliminating labor used to operate the front-end loader or clam shell. Users of grate coolers have profited by increased production in the range of 15 to 20 percent, which is attributed to better burning zone control, which is a function of a more stable draft and secondary air temperature. Improvement of kiln internals with a properly designed lifter section produces even greater fuel savings. The heat consumption of the 1000 ton/day kiln with grate cooler and lifter section is approximately 2,152,265 Btu/ton.

title: Castable thermal insulation for use as heat shields
authors: A. J. Mountvala; Hajime Nakamura; H. L. Rechter
abstract: Structural members supporting the afterburners of high thrust rocket engines are subjected to extreme heating, along with severe vibration and high acceleration levels during early lift-off. Chemically-bonded, castable, zircon composite foams were developed and successfully tested to meet specific, laboratory simulated lift-off conditions.

EARLY HYDRATION OF A SUPERHIGH-EARLY-STRENGTH PORTLAND CEMENT CONTAINING CHROMIUM
abstract: Readily water-soluble, chromium-containing phases exist among the principal clinker minerals of a superhigh-early-strength portland cement manufacturered by adding small amounts of chromium, manganese, and fluorine to the cement raw mix. The effects of these phases on the early hydration of the cement were investigated.

abstract: Taking ceramic engineering and materials science education into the new millennium requires universities to restructure the framework of their educational process. The engineering graduates of tomorrow will shape our destiny.

title: Surface-engineered ceramics : An improved lot
abstract: Engineered ceramic materials frequently possess the required mechanical properties for a specific application but generally lack the surface characteristics--corrosion resistance, oxidation resistance or wear resistance--to prevent fracture initiation effects, environmental degradation and complex tribological interactions. Therefore, it is often more economical to apply a thin coating that possesses the desired properties to the ceramic substrate than it is to fabricate the entire component from more costly or difficult to fabricate materials. Surface coatings engineering, therefore, promises to overcome some of the obvious disadvantages of the ceramic substrate.

title: Space Shuttle - A new era in transportation
abstract: After a brief historical review of the economics of expendable-booster, commercial-payload operations to date, and a description of the Space Shuttle system's design, operational capabilities, and mission profile, the payload flight assignments, materials processing experiments, and Spacelab I material science experiment are detailed. Among the Materials Processing in Space (MPS) fields for investigation are crystal growth from vapor and solution, the production of magnetic composites and metal foams, laser host glasses and metallic glasses, non-buoyancy-driven convections, unidirectional solidification of eutectics, and the solidification of immiscible alloys. Emphasis is put on the long-term, commercial usefulness of such studies, with attention to historical precedents such as the Skylab, Apollo and Apollo-Soyuz programs.

title: Powder processing for fabricating Si{sub 3}N{sub 4} ceramics
authors: Hidehiro Kamiya; Makio Naito; Tadashi Hotta; Kenji Isomura; JunIchiro Tsubaki; Keizo Uematsu
abstract: Usually, the densification of silicon nitride ceramics requires a sintering aid, e.g., alumina and yttria fine powders. Many types of dispersants have been used to obtain a uniform mixture of silicon nitride and sintering aid. These dispersants affect the microstructure and strength of the spray-dried granules. However, few studies have been made of the effects of the microstructure and strength of spray-dried granules. However, few studies have been made of the effects of the microstructure and strength of spray-dried granules on the sintered and mechanical properties of non-oxide ceramics. This article shows the effect of such intergranular porosity--controlled by the strength and structure of spray-dried granules--on the densification of green compacts during sintering. Furthermore, relationships between the fracture strength distribution of spray-dried granules and bending strength distributions of sintered bodies are discussed.

title: SO{sub x} emissions in firing ceramics
abstract: Emissions of sulfur oxides as SO{sub 2} and SO{sub 3}, commonly called SO{sub x}, are regulated under the US Clean Air Act (CAA) as Criteria Pollutants. A regulatory focus has remained on power industry SO{sub x} emissions since passage of the CAA. Moreover, it has been recognized for years that noticeable SO{sub x} emissions also are generated during the firing of traditional ceramics produced from a few, but not all, raw materials. The consequences of these emissions have included scumming and efflorescence phenomena as well as corrosion of metal structures in or near plants. There is increasing pressure from state regulatory agencies to limit SO{sub x} emissions, and Maximum Achievable Control Technology (MACT) criteria under the CAA continue to evolve. Therefore, it is important that ceramic producers understand the sources of SO{sub x} emissions and the strategies for reducing them. Moreover, with proposed new changes in the CAA by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), it is important for the ceramic industry to be able to exert appropriate influence in a time of regulatory uncertainty.

title: Fabrication of Al{sub 2}O{sub 3}-Al composites by reactive melt infiltration
authors: W.-P. Tai; Takanori Watari; Toshio Torikai
abstract: An interpenetrating phase composite (IPC) is a multiphase material in which each phase is topologically interconnected throughout the microstructure. This unique structure provides several mechanical and electrical property advantages to the IPC material against traditional composites with isolated phases. In the present study, near-net-shape Al{sub 2}O{sub 3}-Al composites containing a small amount of silicon metal were fabricated by infiltrating aluminum into Al{sub 2}O{sub 3} particle preforms with the aid of borosilicate glass. This process was conducted under oxygen atmosphere at ambient pressure (1 atm) using a conventional furnace. The growth rate and the mechanical properties of the composites were investigated by changing the processing factors.

title: Evaluating tunnel kiln performance
authors: K.R. O`Connor; William M. Carty; N.J. Ninos
abstract: Process improvements in the production of whitewares provide the potential for substantial savings for manufacturers. A typical whiteware manufacturer incurs an annual defective product loss of {approximately}$20 million when accounting for raw materials, energy, labor and waste disposal. Reduction in defective product loss of 1% could result in a savings in excess of $1 million annually. This study was designed to establish benchmarks for two conventional tunnel kilns used to bisque-fire dinnerware at Buffalo China Inc. (Buffalo, NY). The benchmark was established by assessing the current conditions and variability of the two tunnel kilns as a function of the fracture strength of sample bars that were made from production body. Sample bars were fired in multiple locations in both kilns to assess the conditions and variability of firing within each kiln. Comparison of strength results between the two kilns also was assessed. These comparisons were accomplished through applied statistical analysis, wherein significant statistical variations were identified and isolated for both tunnel kilns. The statistical methods and tools used in this analysis are readily accessible to manufacturers, thus allowing implementation of similar analysis, or benchmarking, in-house.

title: High-temperature fatigue in advanced ceramics
abstract: In recent years, improved processing has produced a new generation of advanced--also described as engineering of fine--ceramics in which the internal defect size if both smaller and more uniform. Mechanical properties are better, and there has been a surge in research interest to demonstrate the value of ceramics as structural materials and thus exploit their traditional superior properties. Popular among this new generation of materials are silicon carbide, silicon nitride and alumina. Enormous potential exists in high-temperature applications, such as gas turbines (blades and disks) and petroleum-based engines (piston rings). In some cases, the limit of the realistic capacity of metallic materials has been reached, and ceramics offer the only route for further progress. To develop design strategies based upon structural integrity, the answers to two questions are essential: what is the size of the defect that will cause fracture under the envisaged loading conditions, and how quickly will any intrinsic defect grow to attain this critical dimension?

title: Determination of sulfur in silicate materials by infrared detection following combustion
abstract: The time consuming and difficult procedure for the determination of sulphur in glass--barium sulfate gravimetry--is replaced by an infrared detection system. This paper presents an evaluation of the analytical capabilities of such a system. The method combusts sulphur in an oxygen atmosphere to evolve sulphur dioxide. The sample is then placed in a crucible, with an accelerator, and burned. The combustion gases are carried into an infrared detector where the amount of sulphur dioxide is displayed. Samples are chosen based on sulphur concentration. The most useful metallic accelerators are porous tungsten and a mixture of iron metal and vanadium pentoxide. Interference by chlorides and nitrates must be calculated into the results.

title: Current refractory trends in refining/petrochemical operations
abstract: Major trends in refractory utilization within the refining/petrochemical industries are discussed. One trend is growth of refractory fiber, particularly modules. Another is the increasing use of stainless steel fibers in monolithic refractories. The third, development of alternate anchorage for erosionresistant linings, is largely interrelated with metal fiber reinforcement.

title: Phase analysis program for magnesia refractories
abstract: Dead-burned magnesia is one of the major raw materials used in the manufacture of refractories that does not melt below 2,500 C. The MgO content, in itself, is not the only factor that is industrially important. Impurity levels are equally important and can affect the slag resistance and high-melting-point properties of the product caused by the formation of low-melting phases, such as monticellite (CMS, CaMgSiO{sub 4} or CaO{center_dot}MgO{center_dot}SiO{sub 2}), merwinite (C{sub 3}MS{sub 2}, Ca{sub 3}Mg(SiO{sub 4}){sub 2} or 3CaO{center_dot}MgO{center_dot}SiO{sub 2}) and bredigite (C{sub 7}MS{sub 4}, Ca{sub 7}Mg(SiO{sub 4}){sub 4} or CaO{center_dot}MgO{center_dot}4SiO{sub 2}). The presence and proportion of these phases are critical, but chemical analysis cannot presently yield such information. CSIRO Division of Mineral Products researchers use the Rietveld method of phase analysis to determine the abundance of individual phase components of various materials, including magnesia refractories. However, for magnesia refractories, the accuracy of the Rietveld results has not yet been tested against an alternative method. The determination of phase abundance by point-counting techniques is a difficult, if not impossible, task. A procedure for calculating the phase compositions from chemical data--such as the Bogue method used in the cement industry--has not been developed yet. This article describes such a method thatmore » is called MAGNORM. MAGNORM calculates normative phase compositions of magnesia refractories from their bulk chemical analyses. Its advantages are the speed that results can be produced from predetermined chemical analysis, the low cost to produce them and consistency. The same rules and assumptions apply to all calculations, allowing more meaningful comparison between samples.« less

title: Behavior of coal slag during gasification
abstract: Coal slag and refractory samples from an entrained slagging gasification process development unit were examined by microscope. Rapid wear of 90% Al/sub 2/O/sub 3/ - 10% Cr/sub 2/O/sub 3/ refractories was caused mainly by dissolution of the refractory matrix and removal of large Al/sub 2/O/sub 3/ grains. Unfired refractories were especially susceptible to this wear mechanism. Alumina grains dissolved in the slag, which resulted in the precipitation of dendritic hercynite during cooling. Reduction of FeO in the slag resulted in the precipitation of mullite crystals. Both mechanisms are believed to increase the apparent viscosity of the slag which can adversely affect slag tapping.

title: Controlling Btu input with high-velocity burners
abstract: StepFire{trademark} (sometimes called pulse fire) controls heat input through a burner by rapidly cycling from high fire to low fire (or from high fire to off) to control the temperature of either an entire kiln or a zone within a kiln. In the StepFire process, each burner, rather than an entire zone of burners, is controlled. The StepFire process provides a better approach to temperature control: high-velocity burners improve temperature distribution across the load, whether the burners are fired vertically downward or horizontally; reentrainment effect of the burners breaks up crown drift and allows dissipation of energy into the product; high-velocity burners generate less NO{sub x} and co than injector-type burners; high-velocity burners put most of the combustion air through the burners and do not have to rely on the mass flow of air from the cooling zone to complete combustion and provide uniformity; individual cycling of the burners does not radically change the total input of gases to the furnace, thereby allowing pressure control; because burners are cycled individually, the entire zone of the furnace does not go from a heating to a cooling mode, but continues at an input rate to maintain uniformity of energy input through themore » stepping process. StepFire use on all types of kilns results in improved product properties and quality, reduced fuel use, increased production, fewer rejects and reduction of NO{sub x} and CO emissions. Because the burners operate under their optimum conditions during most of the firing cycles, NO{sub x} formation is reduced, and the quenching effect of the flame by excess air is not present, reducing the generation of CO.« less

title: NO{sub x} reduction techniques
abstract: NO{sub x} is the combination of nitrogen and oxygen that contributes to acid rain and smog problems. It is formed in high-temperature flames and processes, including kilns and furnaces. Reducing this pollutant is a universal concern, and its regulation will be increased as individual states devise their implementation plans for complying with the US Clean Air Act. The recognized mechanisms for the formation of NO{sub x} in combustion are: Prompt NO{sub x}, which occurs in the flame process of cracking hydrocarbons; Thermal NO{sub x}, which is formed at high temperatures in the presence of free oxygen; and fuel-bond NO{sub x}, which is caused by the conversion of nitrogen atoms attached to a fuel molecule during combustion. NO{sub x} control methods can cause concerns, because they can be costly, complex and do nothing to improve the heating process. Although this is true of several control methods, such as specific catalytic (with ammonia injection) reduction or water injection, there are some methods that can improve the heating process, as well as lower NO{sub x}. In many cases, the temperature uniformity can actually improve, because NO{sub x} reduction techniques frequently lower the localized high flame temperature by mixing the flame with flue gases.more » This article describes some of these methods.« less

title: NDE plays a critical role in advanced ceramics
abstract: Advanced ceramics are becoming increasingly popular because of their excellent structural, electrical, optical and high-temperature properties. Monolithic ceramics, ceramic matrix composites (CMCs) and ceramic coatings are finding applications as cutting tools, engine components, wear parts, bioceramics, insulators, capacitors, integrated circuit (IC) packages, magnets and superconductors. Some of the factors needed for the continued development and commercialization of advanced ceramics are high-quality, low-cost raw materials; improved manufacturing processes, improved reliability; engineering database placement; continued standardization; and innovative testing and characterization techniques. Testing and characterization techniques can have a significant impact on many of the other factors, especially improved reliability. Non-destructive evaluation (NDE) is one technique that has and will continue to play a critical role in the development and manufacturing of advanced ceramics. Industry, government and academia are continuing to make progress in the advancement of NDE techniques for advanced ceramics. This article provides a snapshot of some R and D occurring in this important and evolving area.

title: Forming technology affects refractory performance
abstract: The pressing operation is composed of filling, pressing, measuring and evacuation. Each pressing requires precision in every step to ensure a final product of highest quality. Feeding material into the press and mold cavities is vital for product quality. Material feeding systems with material flow regulators can be designed to accommodate any material in the refractory industry, up to a temperature of 150 C. The material is continuously mixed and homogenized during the entire mold-filling operation so that a uniform fill of all cavities is ensured. Programmable parameters--such as number and direction of rotations, amount of material to be filled and positioning of the mixing tools--allow for easy adaptation to any refractory material, whether processed in single-cavity or multicavity operations. A further advantage of the feeding system is the programming of all switching points and speeds for mold and the charger box movements. If the relative speeds are selected properly, tapered filling and other fill configurations can be achieved with extreme repetitive accuracy.

title: Defect equilibria and transport in YBa 2 Cu 3 O 7 -x at elevated temperatures 2
Bag-house dust used in clinkerization of portland cements
authors: N.B. Singh; K.N. Bhattacharjee; Anjani Kumar Shukla
abstract: Many industrial materials considered essential for supporting a better quality of life consume large amounts of energy for their production. Ordinary portland cement (OPC) is used widely as a building material, and its manufacture consumes much energy. In India, the cost of energy accounts for >40% of the total cost of cement manufacture. The cost to manufacture cement is expected to increase because of increasing demands for energy. Scientists are attempting to prepare OPC and other binding materials at lower cost by using agricultural and industrial wastes during clinkerization and by making blended cements. These measures decrease cost of production, conserve mineral resources and protect the environment by beneficial disposal of wastes. This article describes the effect of adding 10% bag-house dust to black meal used in vertical shaft kiln clinkerization in a cement miniplant. The hydration properties of OPC and blended cements made from control and experimental clinkers also have been studied.

title: Glassmakers face new emissions concerns
abstract: Although pure-oxygen-based combustion has been available for many years, it is becoming more widely accepted in today`s glass industry. It enables glass producers to: pull more glass; use less fuel in melting; reduce furnace costs; remove costly regenerators and recuperators; reduce furnace exhaust flow rate. However, emissions concerns and problems have developed along with the benefits. Glass manufacturers are searching for methods to produce a quality product in the shortest amount of time with the least amount of fuel. Oxy-fuel firing presents an attractive alternative to conventional firing that combines profit with environmental regulation compliance. Oxy-fuel firing can be a glass manufacturer`s best retrofit alternative for NO{sub x} PM{sub 10}, and SO{sub x} reduction because increases process quality and productivity and may lower costs.

title: Effect of temperature on fracture behavior of plastic refractories
abstract: Various grades of plastic refractories were studied to characterize fracture parameters, especially work of fracture, as a function of temperature. Significant differences in the work of fracture trends are noted for clay and sulfate (air-bonded) plastics vs those with phosphate bonds. Results obtained from this initial survey are interesting and show the need for continued, detailed evaluation of plastic refractories. Evaluation of the effect of aggregate type and grain sizing needs to be expanded in scope. Likewise, more detailed work on various bond systems is needed.

title: Testing advanced structural ceramics
authors: Chao Zong Zhang; Zhiping Guo; Yufeng Dong; Heping Zhang; Jiemo Tian
abstract: Nondestructive evaluation (NDE) methods are important both to guarantee the reliability of ceramic components and to optimize the fabrication process. Radiography is one of the most common NDE methods used. However, conventional radiography yields an overlapping shadow graph of an object, and all features of a 3D object are projected to a 2D image. Therefore, detectable defects -- especially cracks -- depend on their orientation. As an advanced form of radiography technology, X-ray computed tomography (CT) overcomes the disadvantages of common projection radiography and provides easily recognized cross-section images of the inspected object. Therefore, it accurately shows the spatial location and size of defects as well as the density of the regions of interest in a material. A fluorescopy-based CT experimental system was operational by 1990. A new, industrial computed tomography (ICT) system with discrete detectors for NDE of advanced structural ceramics is based on the preliminary ICT work.

title: Ternary phases in three-dimension
abstract: The use of phase diagrams is fundamental to engineering new materials and to process optimization and debugging in the manufacture of well-established materials and products. Although proper interpretation of binary-phase diagrams is generally straightforward, ternary diagrams are, to some, more intimidating. A number of subtle rules must be followed to determine the cooling path of a chosen composition, and composition/temperature correlations require extrapolation between distant isotherms on the diagram. Software has been developed that follows these rules with digital precision, so that greater accuracy can be extracted from the diagrams and misinterpretations can be avoided. The software inputs a data file containing the coordinates of compounds, boundary lines and isotherms, as well as their names and values. Based on this, least-squares polynomial surfaces can be fit to primary phase fields and polynomial curves fit to phase boundaries. A 3-D ternary diagram can then be rendered and phase calculations performed from these curves. The code is written to input a data file representing any ternary system, although presently, only the CaO-Al{sub 2}O{sub 3}-SiO{sub 2} system has been used. This system is plate No. 1 in the 10 large-scale ternary system diagrams published by the American Ceramic Society. This program immediately servesmore » as a useful teaching tool on how to interpret a ternary phase diagram. It is anticipated that the next version of the code will contain all 10 of the large-scale diagram plates. This will require additional algorithms to handle solid solutions and liquid immiscibility.« less

title: Update on copper oxide superconductors
abstract: The early high-{Tc} superconductors Ba{sub 2}YCu{sub 3}O{sub 7} and Bi{sub 2}Sr{sub 2}Ca{sub 2}Cu{sub 3}O{sub 10} remain the most studied for their potential application. The number and variety of new copper oxide superconductors discovered since 1986 is remarkable. Although physicists like to take credit for the superconductivity revolution, it is really a revolution in new materials. New materials of continually increasing complexity have driven the field forward since its beginning. It is no accident that the chemically simplest copper oxide superconductors were discovered first. Higher {Tc} values have been caused by the rapid growth in general knowledge in the material community of the empirical factors necessary for the occurrence of high-{Tc} superconductivity. The growth is based on improving chemical understanding of previous discoveries. The chemical understanding and complexity of cuprate superconductors continue to increase. The appearance in 1993 of mercury-based materials has further raised {Tc} values.

title: Property Database for Gas-Fired Application of Ceramics
abstract: Enhancing the utilization of natural gas is the primary goal of the research and development efforts in gas-specific technologies at the Center for Advanced Materials (CAM). It is widely anticipated that ceramic materials will play an important and, perhaps, crucial role in that goal in the near future. The success of such efforts will depend vitally on the accessibility of critical materials property data. The design engineer needs to know that such a database exists, how to access it, and how to use it. The computerized Property Database for Gas-Fired Applications of Ceramics, presented in this paper, is focused on specific applications, materials, and properties, and is the key to the success of these efforts. As a result, CAM is sponsoring research to develop a prototype, gas-specific, materials properties database that is centered on structural ceramics for such applications as heat exchangers and recuperators.

title: Refractories; At the heart of high-temperature processing
abstract: This paper reports that every industry that employs high-temperature process heat, from foundries and steel plants to glass furnaces and cement kilns, depends heavily on refractories. As higher temperatures are demanded in many applications, new materials are processed and new operating techniques employed, the need for refractories is intensified. The ability of refractories to meet the new requirements is due, in no small measure, to the continuing research and development programs of the industry, resulting in new materials with advanced properties to meet changing needs. Although a number of leading British refractory manufacturers undertake much of this work, overall support is provided by the Refractories Association of Great Britain (RAGB).

title: The refractories of the People's Republic of China; An advancing industry
abstract: The author discusses the International Symposium on Refractories (ISR) in Hangzhou. This meeting was jointly sponsored and organized by the Chinese Society of Metals and the Chinese Silicate Society. Technical presentations discussed the status of refractory raw materials, refractories for the metallurgical industry, and refractories for the cement and glass industries among other topics.

title: FRCMCs, a sample preparation challenge
abstract: Fiber-reinforced ceramic matrix composites (FRCMCs) have found increasing use in engineering applications requiring light weight, high strength and rigidity, adequate thermal and chemical stability, resistance to wear and ablation and graceful failure characteristics. Continued investments in CMC research and development by agencies such as DOD, NASA, DOE, NSF and NIST demonstrate increased interest in the field. An important part of the R and D process in the analysis of composites during various stages of processing, after testing (physical, thermal, chemical) and after successful or failed operative use. Interpretation of structure/property correlations plays a major role in determining how well a composite is suited to a given engineering environment. Various forms of microstructural analysis ultimately help the materials scientist adjust compositional and processing parameters to tailor the properties of the composite. Accurate microstructural analysis of fiber-reinforced ceramic matrix composite depends upon proper microstructural preparation techniques. Composites exhibit unusual characteristics that make sample preparation especially challenging.

title: Improvement of the electrical properties of glass by lithia addition
abstract: The electrical properties of toughened glass insulators used in transmission lines are of great importance. The electrical properties of glass insulators can be improved, while maintaining low viscosities and other desirable forming properties, by the the depressing effect' (i.e., the effect of substituting alkaline-earth oxides for a part of the SiO[sub 2] when developing a glass composition). To satisfy some specific application needs, a combination of both the depressing effect and mixed-alkali effect should be considered. The common practice of the latter essentially relies on increasing the ratio of K[sub 2]O to Na[sub 2]O in the glass, which, from a theoretical standpoint, undoubtedly results in better electrical properties of the glass, but with some unfavorable impact on the viscosity of the glass which may preclude its regular use. However, previous studies have shown that the mixed-alkali effect varies with the types of ions present. In the present paper the authors report on an investigation of the substitution of Li[sub 2]O for K[sub 2]O, which increases the resistivity but maintains the low viscosity.

title: Permeability of HTR fuel element graphite for technetium, cesium, and neptunium
abstract: Spent fuel from the operating German High Temperature Gas Cooled Reactor THTR-300 (300 MWe) will not be reprocessed but stored in a final repository after suitable conditioning. An accidental ingress of water into the repository could lead to the formation of a brine solution which may corrode the multiple barrier system components and leach radionuclides from the fuel microspheres. Mobilized material would then migrate through the porous graphite hull which forms an integral part of the spherical fuel element. Although retardation capabilities of this graphite were not presumed, it was of interest to investigate its permeability for some typical long-lived radionuclides such as Tc-99, Cs-137, and Np-237 in order to supply data for the safety assessment of the final repository. It was shown that radionuclides permeate through graphite to a considerable extent, especially from fuel elements undergoing pressure cycles when stored under a brine solution.

title: Ceramics for controlling diesel emissions
abstract: As the use of diesel-powered vehicles continues to increase around the world, serious concerns regarding their emulsion particulates effects on public health and the environment are resulting in tighter and tighter standards. Ceramics show promise in providing a solution to meeting these standards. Applications were discussed in a special session at the 1993 SAE Congress and are mentioned in this paper.

title: Ceramic fabricator quality revolution : a case study
abstract: This case study discusses statistical process control and other quality tools in the application of continuous improvement and total quality management programs to a mature ceramic parts manufacturing operation that had been producing quality'' products for many years. By applying these tools, significant incremental improvements in process performance and product quality were achieved.

title: MHD air preheaters: results of thermomechanical tests
abstract: The thermomechanical tests conducted on four different high-purity periclase magnesia-fired brick were used to select suitable refractory material for the design of a regenerative heat exchanger (Cowper type) for an open-cycle indirect preheating, MHD pilot plant. Tests were conducted under the most severe temperature condition allowable in standard test equipment. The choice among the refractories were made supposing that the ranking established with these tests does not change for higher temperatures (up to 1,900 C). Refractory material M1 exhibited the best behavior. The reported values can be used for the preliminary design of the heat exchanger, using the appropriate safety coefficient. The effective behavior of the materials can be completely understood only with experimental data obtained by the effective operation condition, because size and shape of the material strongly affect the service behavior. The best test is a pilot plant, using scaled-down criteria. This will overcome the difficulty of the standard test at 1,900 C, caused by test equipment limitations.

title: Fluidized mixing: The efficient way to combine bulk powders
abstract: Mechanical mixers are predominant in bulk powder blending installations, but fluidized systems offer many indisputable advantages in efficiency, power consumption, and maintenance costs. It is clear that maintenance is one of the major considerations today when choosing a blending system. Power must also be considered when making a decision on the type of equipment to be operated. Power to drive air is far less than the power required to mechanically move an entire bin or its contents. The mechanical mixer requires much more energy to operate.

title: Characterization of Jet Milled Silicon Powders
authors: P. D. Ownby; S. A. Howard; Jesus Mendoza; M. W. Jones; J.K.F. Yau

title: Operating characteristics of a cartridge collector utilizing medium-pressure purge air
abstract: For over 20 years, dust collectors equipped with cleanable paper cartridge pulse-jet cleaning mechanisms. Applications have been limited primarily to light inlet dust loads of 2 grains/dscf (4.6g/m[sup 3] or less). One manufacturer has successfully tested and operated a dust collector utilizing a full-scale, medium-pressure (6 to 8 psig, 4.0 to 5.5 MPa), utilizing 6-in. (150-mm) diameter by 50-in. (1,270-mm) cellulose cartridge filter elements, under high inlet dust load conditions.

title: DISCONTINUOUS WET-GRINDING OF RAW-MATERIALS IN THE PRODUCTION OF TRADITIONAL CERAMIC TILES
authors: T. Mandredini; Gian Carlo Pellacani; Paolo Pozzi; Anna Corradi Bonamartini
abstract: Etude au laboratoire et a l'echelle semi-industrielle du broyage humide discontinu des matieres premieres utilisees pour la preparation des barbotines pour carreaux ceramiques. On insiste sur l'importance du controle de la distribution granulometrique et de la viscosite, ainsi que des caracteristiques mineralogiques des residus de broyage.

title: Effects of glazing technologies on tile surface properties
authors: L. Esposito; A. Tucci; Giorgio Timellini; A. Fontana

title: 微粒子用の高効率エアフィルタ(HEPA)の新しい発展
MHD air preheaters: Preliminary firing tests for materials selection
abstract: The development of power generation by MHD involves many basic and engineering questions. A critical problem is the selection, design and fabrication of construction materials for components, particularly for the air preheaters. Their durability and reliability must be guaranteed for thousands of hours. Open-cycle MHD power plants have indirect air preheating using Cowper-type regenerators. The maximum temperature that can be obtained with the preheating system depends upon the thermo-mechanical properties of the materials used. Commercially available magnesia, alumina and zirconia were fired at 1800, 1850, 1950 and 2000 C with 12-h soak times. The results show that the magnesia-based materials with a high content of pure periclase magnesia are the most promising for air preheater application in a MHD power plant with an indirect preheating system. Four samples behaved well after the 2000 C firing test. Further thermomechanical tests are necessary to select the most suitable materials and to decide the maximum working temperature of the materials. If direct preheating is used, the materials selected might not be the most suitable.

title: CERAMIC RESEARCH IN BELGIUM
abstract: For centuries, the ceramic industry in Belgium has been involved in the production of traditional products, such as bricks, tile, chinaware, and refractories. Currently there are over 6,000 people working in the industry with a turnover of more than 350 million ECU. However, fifteen years ago research in advanced ceramics began in several major research institutes and eventually became almost the single research interest for the majority of universities and research institutes. In fact, each university now has at least one team working in advanced ceramics, who usually come from other backgrounds such as metallurgy. Here, a review if some of these research programs is given.

title: EFFECT OF MILLING ON THE CAST MICROSTRUCTURE AND SINTERING BEHAVIOR OF MGO PARTIALLY-STABILIZED ZRO2
PREPARATION OF BARIUM LEAD TITANATES WITH CURIE POINTS ABOVE 300-DEGREES-C AND THEIR PTCR CHARACTERISTICS
PREPARATION AND PROPERTIES OF MO METALLIZED SIC/BEO SUBSTRATE
authors: Tamotsu Ueyama; Yasuharu Horibe; Yoshiko Miya

title: Evolution of technology transfer in Latin America.
abstract: The author discusses how Latin American countries have grown up buying technology, transferring technology from more developed nations, and attempting to adapt it to their own countries for their own environment. Although this is the approach that was and is necessary, there are still some shortfalls that have occurred in the process of licensing and acquisition of technology. Governments around the world also have had powerful impacts on technology transfer. Those in Latin America are no exception.

title: A new liquid-phase-separation glaze containing neodymium oxide
authors: Jing Sun; Chen Xianque; Kang Luxing; Joseph L. Pentecost
abstract: A color-changeable opaque glaze containing neodymium oxide was investigated. Results show that the glaze is a new example of the liquid-phase-separation type. The discrete phase droplets are from 50 to 500 nm in size. They are rich in Nd, Zn, Ca, and Mg and the continuous phase is rich in Si, Al, and K. The concentration of the discrete phase is approx. =45%. The large number of discrete droplets and the zinc oxide in the glaze increase its opacity to cover the selective light absorption and scattering of the neodymium ion and reduce the opalescence effect.

title: Improved zircon iron corals for the 1990s
abstract: CIBA-GEIGY/Drakenfeld Colors is dedicated to the research and development of consistent and cost-effective ceramic stains for the whitewares industry. After identifying the trends in color for the 1990s. CIBA-GEIGY/Drakenfeld Colors initiated an extensive R D project to improve zircon ion corals for the whitewares industry. These color trends indicated a need for stronger and cleaner zircon iron corals. This paper discusses the chemistry and crystal structure of zircon iron corals. A historical review of Drakenfeld corals will also be presented. The most recent development in Drakenfeld corals will then be compared to other commercially available zircon iron corals. Taking into consideration these comparisons, conclusions will be drawn suggesting the coral of choice for the 1990s.

title: DESIGN AND SPECIFICATION OF FLEXIBLE BRICK PAVEMENTS
abstract: Brick pavements can be generally classified in two ways: flexible brick pavements and rigid brick pavements. A flexible brick paving system consists of a well-compacted subgrade beneath a layer of crushed stone, a sand setting bed, and sand between the pavers. On the other hand, rigid brick paving is most commonly identified by the presence of mortar joints. This article deals mainly with flexible brick pavements in roads and streets.
